facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1974 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1974.

facts.text: The appeal arises from the Judgment and Order dated 1st October 1973 of the Delhi High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 170 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment aid Order dated the 1st October, 1973 of the Delhi High Court at New Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 170 of 1972.

facts.text: The accused-appellant has a shop at Kishan Ganj, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The accused has a shop at Kishan Ganj, Delhi.

facts.text: On 1st February 1972, the accused sold a packet of playing cards portraying luridly obscene naked pictures of men and women in pornographic sexual postures to P.W. 1.

anchor.surface_text: It is numbermore in companytroversy that on 1st February, 1972, the accused sold a packet of playing cards portraying on the reverse luridly obscene naked pictures of men and women in pornog

facts.text: The sale was arranged by the police Sub-Inspector P.W. 4 on receipt of secret information about the accused uttering these obscene pictures.

anchor.surface_text: This sale was arranged by the police Sub-Inspector  P.W. 4  on receipt of secret information about the accused uttering these obscene pictures.

facts.text: On getting a signal from the purchaser, a raid was made in the accused's shop where two more packets of such obscene cards were recovered in addition to the packet sold to P.W. 1.

anchor.surface_text: On getting a signal from the purchaser a raid was made in the accuseds shop when two more packets of such obscene cards were also recovered in addition to the packet already sold to P.W. 1.

facts.text: The ten-rupee note, which was the price of the set of playing cards given by the Sub-Inspector to P.W. 1, was recovered from the person of the accused.

anchor.surface_text: The ten-rupee numbere, which was the price of the said set of playing cards and which had been earlier given-by the Sub-Inspector to P.W. 1, was also recovered from the person of the accused.

facts.text: At the trial, the accused was convicted under section 292 Indian Penal Code and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 500, in default three months further rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial the accused was companyvicted under section 292, Indian Penal Code and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment and to a fine of Rs. 500/-, in default further rigorous imprisonment for three months.

facts.text: The Delhi High Court affirmed the conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court affirmed the companyviction as well as the sentence.

facts.text: The appeal is by special leave and limited to the question of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is limited only to the question of sentence in a companyviction of the accused- appellant under section 292, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Obscenity of the playing cards recovered from the accused is not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: Since obscenity of the playing cards recovered from the accused is number challenged and for the matter of that the companyviction under section 292, I.P.C.,

facts.text: Learned counsel for appellant submits that only one single sale was established and only three packets of cards were recovered.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the appellant submits that the sentence is very severe on the ground that only one single sale has been established in this case and also only three packets of cards were recovered from the accused.

facts.text: Section 292 IPC was amended by Act XXXVI of 1969, enhancing the penalty.

anchor.surface_text: This section was amended by Act XXXVI of 1969 when apart from enlarging the scope of the exceptions, the penalty was enhanced which was earlier up to three months or with fine or with both.

facts.text: The accused is married and is said to be 36 years of age.

anchor.surface_text: The accused is married and is said to be 36 years of ago.

facts.text: The Supreme Court rejected the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, rejected.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant submitted that the accused is entitled to probation under section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: He further submits that the accused is entitled to be released on probation under section 4 of the probation of Offenders Act, 1958.

facts.text: The Supreme Court declined to release the accused on probation.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the circumstances of the case and the nature of the offence and the potential danger of the accuseds activity in this nefarious trade affecting the morals of society particularly of the young, we are number prepared to release him under section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 292 1 reads as follows - 292 1 For the purpose of sub-section  2 , a book, pamphlet, paper, writing, drawing, painting, representation or figure or any other object, shall be deemed to be obscene, if it is lascivious or appeals to the prurient interest or if its effect, or  where it comprises two or more items  the effect of any one of its items, is, if taken as a whole, such as to tend to deprave and corrupt persons who are likely, having regard to all relevant circumstances to read, see or bear the matter contained or embodied in it.

concepts.unlisted_description: A thing is obscene if lascivious, appeals to prurient interest, or tends to deprave and corrupt likely viewers taken as a whole

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  2  of section 292 is the penal provision which runs as follows - 292  2 Whoever- sells, lets to hire, distributes, publicly exhibits or in any manner puts into circulation, or for purposes of sale, hire, distribution, public exhibition or circulation, makes, produces or has in his possession any obscene book, pamphlet, paper, drawing, painting, representation or figure or any other obscene object whatsoever shall be punished on first conviction with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years. and with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees

arguments.court_reasoning: Not expedient given circumstances of case, nature of offence, potential danger of accused's activity affecting morals of society particularly the young.

arguments.claim: Leniency in sentencing not warranted due to 1969 amendment to section 292 IPC enhancing penalties and reflecting legislative intent to protect society especially younger generation from corrupting influence of obscene materials.

anchor.surface_text: This section was amended by Act XXXVI of 1969 when apart from enlarging the scope of the exceptions, the penalty was enhanced which was earlier up to three months or with fine or with both. By the amendment a dichotomy of penal treatment was introduced... The intention of the legislature is, therefore, made clear by the amendment in 1969 in dealing with this type of offences which corrupt the minds of people to whom these objectionable things can easily reach and it need not be emphasised that the corrupting influence of these pictures is more likely to be upon the younger generation who has got to be protected from being easy prey to these libidinous appeals upon which this illicit trade is based. We are, therefore, not prepared to accept the submission of the learned counsel to deal with the accused leniently in this case.

arguments.claim: Accused not to be released on probation under section 4 of Probation of Offenders Act given circumstances, nature of offence, character of offender, and potential danger to society's morals particularly the young.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the plea of the learned counsel on the score of section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act, we may read the section Power to Court to release certain offenders on probation of good conduct 4(1) When any person is found guilty of having committed an offence not punishable with death or imprisonment for life and the Court by which the person is found guilty is of opinion that, having regard to the circumstances of the case including the nature of the offence and the character of the offender, it is expedient, to release him on probation of good conduct... The accused is married and is said to be 36 years of age. Having regard to the circumstances of the case and the nature of the offence and the potential danger of the accuseds activity in this nefarious trade affecting the morals of society particularly of the young, we are not prepared to release him under section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act.

arguments.claim: Offences of corrupting the mind through obscenity must be treated on the same footing as food adulteration cases with no leniency.

anchor.surface_text: These offences of corrupting the internal fabric of the mind have got to be treated on the same footing as the cases of food adulterators and we are not prepared to show any leniency.

holdings.text: The court is not prepared to accept the submission to deal with the accused leniently in sentencing for conviction under section 292 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The intention of the legislature is, therefore, made clear by the amendment in 1969 in dealing with this type of offences which corrupt the minds of people to whom these objectionable things can easily reach and it need not be emphasised that the corrupting influence of these pictures is more likely to be upon the younger generation who has got to be protected from being easy prey to these libidinous appeals upon which this illicit trade is based. We are, therefore, not prepared to accept the submission of the learned counsel to deal with the accused leniently in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative amendment in 1969 enhanced penalties for first and subsequent convictions to deter offences corrupting minds, especially youth; sentence of 6 months RI and Rs 500 fine appropriate within limits.

holdings.text: The accused is not to be released on probation under section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the circumstances of the case and the nature of the offence and the potential danger of the accuseds activity in this nefarious trade affecting the morals of society particularly of the young, we are not prepared to release him under section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not expedient considering circumstances, nature of offence, character of offender, and danger to society's morals especially youth; section requires court opinion on expediency.

holdings.text: Offences corrupting the mind through obscenity are to be treated on the same footing as food adulteration cases with no leniency.

anchor.surface_text: These offences of corrupting the internal fabric of the mind have got to be treated on the same footing as the cases of food adulterators and we are not prepared to show any leniency.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obscenity offences undermine moral fabric akin to physical harm from adulteration; demands strict sentencing to protect society.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sentence affirmed; no basis for reduction or probation.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, rejected.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal rejected; sentence upheld without leniency or release on probation under section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act
